'''Lonnie Pitchford''' (October 8, 1955 – November 8, 1998) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[musician]] and [[musical instrument|instrument]] maker from [[Lexington, Mississippi|Lexington]], [[Mississippi]].  He was notable in that he was one of only a handful of young [[African American]] [[musician]]s from Mississippi who had learned and was continuing the [[Delta blues]] and [[country blues]] traditions of the older generations.

In addition to the [[acoustic guitar|acoustic]] and [[electric guitar]], Pitchford was also skilled at the one-string guitar and [[diddley bow]], a one-string instrument of [[Africa]]n origin, as well as the [[double bass]], [[piano]] and [[harmonica]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]]
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 156
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>  He was a protégé of [[Robert Lockwood, Jr.]], from whom he learned the style of [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]].<ref name="russell"/> His own debut [[album]], ''All Round Man'' was released on Rooster Blues Records in 1994.<ref name="russell"/>

In November 1998, Pitchford died at his home in Lexington, from [[AIDS]].  A diddley bow is featured on his [[headstone]] which was paid for by [[John Fogerty]] and Rooster Blues Records through the [[Mt. Zion Memorial Fund]]. His [[grave (burial)|grave]] is located near the grave of [[Elmore James]], in the New Port Baptist Church [[cemetery]] in [[Holmes County, Mississippi]].
